fields.name: Biology
fields.description: The study of living organisms and their interactions with the environment.

fields.name: Astronomy
fields.description: The study of celestial bodies and the universe beyond Earth's atmosphere.

fields.name: Psychology
fields.description: The science of behavior and mental processes.

fields.name: Environmental Science
fields.description: The study of the environment and how to protect it.

fields.name: Mathematics
fields.description: The abstract study of numbers, patterns, and structures.

fields.name: Geology
fields.description: The science of the Earth, its materials, processes, and history.

fields.name: Sociology
fields.description: The study of social behavior, organizations, and institutions.

fields.name: Economics
fields.description: The study of production, consumption, and distribution of goods and services.

fields.name: Computer Science
fields.description: The study of computational systems, algorithms, and data processing.

fields.name: Medicine
fields.description: The science of diagnosing, treating, and preventing illness.

fields.name: Engineering
fields.description: The application of scientific principles to design and build systems, machines, and structures.

fields.name: Anthropology
fields.description: The study of humans, their behavior, and societies.

fields.name: Political Science
fields.description: The study of governments, political systems, and public policies.

fields.name: Physics
fields.description: The study of matter, energy, and the fundamental forces of nature.

fields.name: Chemistry
fields.description: The science of substances, their properties, and reactions.

fields.name: Christianity
fields.description: A monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus Christ.

fields.name: Islam
fields.description: A monotheistic religion that believes in Allah and follows the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad.

fields.name: Hinduism
fields.description: An ancient religion originating in India, characterized by a belief in reincarnation and a supreme being with many forms.

fields.name: Buddhism
fields.description: A religion and philosophy founded by Siddhartha Gautama (the Buddha) focused on achieving enlightenment and escaping suffering.

fields.name: Judaism
fields.description: A monotheistic religion of the Jewish people, based on the Torah and other Hebrew scriptures.

fields.name: Sikhism
fields.description: A monotheistic religion founded in Punjab by Guru Nanak, emphasizing equality and devotion to God.

fields.name: Shinto
fields.description: The traditional religion of Japan, centered on the worship of kami (spirits) and nature.

fields.name: Taoism
fields.description: A philosophical and religious tradition of Chinese origin emphasizing living in harmony with the Tao.

fields.name: Confucianism
fields.description: A philosophy and system of ethics originating in China, based on the teachings of Confucius.

fields.name: Zoroastrianism
fields.description: An ancient Persian religion founded by Zoroaster, emphasizing dualism between good and evil.

fields.name: Jainism
fields.description: An ancient Indian religion advocating for non-violence, truth, and asceticism.

fields.name: Baha'i Faith
fields.description: A monotheistic religion emphasizing the spiritual unity of all humankind, founded by Bahá'u'lláh.

fields.name: Animism
fields.description: A belief system that all things, including animals, plants, and inanimate objects, have a spirit.

fields.name: Paganism
fields.description: A broad term for polytheistic religions often associated with ancient or indigenous traditions.

fields.name: Druze
fields.description: A monotheistic religion originating in the Middle East, combining elements of Islam and other philosophies.

fields.name: Rastafarianism
fields.description: A religion originating in Jamaica, emphasizing African heritage and the worship of Haile Selassie.

fields.name: Scientology
fields.description: A modern religion founded by L. Ron Hubbard, focusing on self-improvement and spiritual enlightenment.

fields.name: Unitarian Universalism
fields.description: A liberal religion characterized by a free and responsible search for truth and meaning.

fields.name: Vodou
fields.description: A syncretic religion practiced primarily in Haiti, blending African traditions with Christianity.

fields.name: Cao Dai
fields.description: A syncretic religion originating in Vietnam, combining elements of many world religions.

fields.name: Tenrikyo
fields.description: A Japanese religion founded by Miki Nakayama, focused on the divine nature of humanity.

fields.name: Raelism
fields.description: A UFO religion founded by Claude Vorilhon, teaching that life on Earth was created by extraterrestrial beings.

fields.name: Wicca
fields.description: A modern pagan religion focused on nature worship, magic, and personal spiritual growth.

fields.name: Atheism
fields.description: A lack of belief in gods or deities, often characterized by skepticism or rejection of religious claims.

fields.name: Agnosticism
fields.description: A belief that the existence of gods or deities is unknown or unknowable, often involving skepticism or doubt.

fields.name: Humanism
fields.description: A philosophical and ethical stance emphasizing the value and agency of human beings, often rejecting supernatural beliefs.

fields.name: Existentialism
fields.description: A philosophical movement emphasizing individual freedom, choice, and responsibility in a seemingly indifferent universe.

fields.name: Stoicism
fields.description: A school of philosophy founded in ancient Greece, emphasizing self-control, virtue, and acceptance of fate.

fields.name: Hedonism
fields.description: A philosophical stance emphasizing pleasure and happiness as the highest good.

fields.name: Nihilism
fields.description: A philosophical belief that life is without objective meaning, purpose, or intrinsic value.

fields.name: Utilitarianism
fields.description: A moral theory emphasizing the greatest happiness for the greatest number of people.

fields.name: Objectivism
fields.description: A philosophical system developed by Ayn Rand, emphasizing rational self-interest and individualism.

fields.name: Feminism
fields.description: A social and political movement advocating for the rights and equality of women.

fields.name: Socialism
fields.description: A political and economic system advocating for collective ownership and control of the means of production.

fields.name: Capitalism
fields.description: An economic system based on private ownership of the means of production and the pursuit of profit.

fields.name: Communism
fields.description: A political and economic system advocating for a classless society and common ownership of the means of production.

fields.name: Libertarianism
fields.description: A political philosophy emphasizing individual liberty, free markets, and limited government intervention.

fields.name: Anarchism
fields.description: A political philosophy advocating for the abolition of hierarchical authority and the establishment of voluntary cooperation.

fields.name: Fascism
fields.description: A far-right political ideology emphasizing authoritarianism, nationalism, and the supremacy of the state.

fields.name: Environmentalism
fields.description: A political and social movement advocating for the protection and preservation of the natural environment.

fields.name: Nationalism
fields.description: A political ideology emphasizing the interests and culture of a particular nation, often to the exclusion of others.

fields.name: Pacifism
fields.description: A belief in non-violence and opposition to war or conflict as a means of resolving disputes.

fields.name: Liberalism
fields.description: A political and social philosophy emphasizing individual rights, democracy, and the rule of law.

fields.name: Conservatism
fields.description: A political philosophy emphasizing tradition, authority, and the preservation of established institutions.

fields.name: Protectionism
fields.description: The economic policy of restricting imports from other countries through methods such as tariffs on imported goods, import quotas, and a variety of other government regulations.

fields.name: Interventionism
fields.description: The belief that a state or group of states has the moral, political, or strategic obligation to actively intervene in the affairs of other nations—through military force, economic pressure, or diplomatic coercion—to achieve specific ends deemed universally beneficial or essential to the intervener’s worldview.

fields.name: Populims
fields.description: A political ideology that emphasizes the will of "the people" against a perceived elite or establishment, often transcending traditional left-right divides.

fields.name: Populism
fields.description: A political ideology that emphasizes the will of 'the people' against a perceived elite or establishment, often transcending traditional left-right divides.

fields.name: Technocracy
fields.description: An ideology advocating for governance by experts, typically scientists or engineers, based on technical knowledge rather than political affiliation.

fields.name: Globalism
fields.description: An ideology promoting interconnectedness, free trade, and supranational cooperation over national sovereignty.

fields.name: Isolationism
fields.description: A policy or ideology favoring non-involvement in international affairs, prioritizing domestic focus and self-sufficiency.

fields.name: Progressivism
fields.description: A political and social ideology advocating for reform, modernization, and social justice, often challenging traditional structures.

fields.name: Pragmatism
fields.description: A philosophical approach emphasizing practical consequences and real-world applications as the basis for truth and meaning.

fields.name: Absurdism
fields.description: A philosophy, linked to existentialism, asserting that the universe is inherently meaningless, yet humans must create their own purpose.

fields.name: Epicureanism
fields.description: An ancient Greek philosophy teaching that pleasure (moderately pursued) and the avoidance of pain are the highest goods.

fields.name: Phenomenology
fields.description: A philosophical method focusing on the structures of experience and consciousness as they appear to the individual.

fields.name: Postmodernism
fields.description: A philosophical and cultural movement questioning grand narratives, objective truth, and embracing relativism and diversity.

fields.name: Falun Gong
fields.description: A modern Chinese spiritual practice blending Buddhist and Taoist elements, emphasizing meditation, morality, and energy cultivation.

fields.name: Yazidism
fields.description: An ancient monotheistic religion from the Kurdish region, centered on the worship of a supreme God and reverence for the Peacock Angel.

fields.name: Theosophy
fields.description: A spiritual movement founded by Helena Blavatsky, blending Eastern and Western esoteric traditions to explore universal wisdom.

fields.name: Sufism
fields.description: A mystical branch of Islam focused on spiritual purification, divine love, and direct experience of God.

fields.name: Satanism (LaVeyan)
fields.description: A modern atheistic religion founded by Anton LaVey, emphasizing individualism, skepticism, and symbolic rebellion against traditional norms.

fields.name: Neuroscience
fields.description: The scientific study of the nervous system, brain function, and their relation to behavior and cognition.

fields.name: Linguistics
fields.description: The scientific study of language, its structure, evolution, and social use.

fields.name: Archaeology
fields.description: The study of human history and prehistory through the excavation and analysis of artifacts and physical remains.

fields.name: Ecology
fields.description: The scientific study of interactions between organisms and their environments.

fields.name: Statistics
fields.description: The science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting numerical data to understand patterns and make predictions.

fields.name: Evolution (Darwinism)
fields.description: A scientific theory proposing that species develop through natural selection and adaptation over time.

fields.name: Psychoanalysis (Freudianism)
fields.description: A theory and therapeutic method developed by Sigmund Freud, emphasizing the unconscious mind, repression, and early experiences.

fields.name: Relativity
fields.description: Albert Einstein’s theory describing the relationship between space, time, gravity, and energy, revolutionizing physics.

fields.name: Quantum Theory
fields.description: A scientific framework explaining the behavior of matter and energy at microscopic scales, challenging classical physics.

fields.name: Systems Theory
fields.description: An interdisciplinary theory studying complex systems, their interactions, and emergent properties across natural and social sciences.

fields.name: Woke Ideology
fields.description: A social and political stance emphasizing awareness of systemic injustices—particularly around race, gender, and class—and advocating for progressive change to address them. Often tied to concepts like intersectionality and critical theory.

fields.name: LGBT Movement
fields.description: A social and political movement advocating for the rights, recognition, and equality of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals, often extending to broader queer identities. Emphasizes liberation from traditional norms and legal protections.

fields.name: Queer Theory
fields.description: An intellectual framework and ideology questioning fixed categories of gender and sexuality, advocating for fluidity and the deconstruction of normative social structures. Rooted in postmodernism and often linked to LGBT activism.

fields.name: Intersectionality
fields.description: An ideology and analytical framework asserting that overlapping social identities (e.g., race, gender, class) create unique experiences of oppression or privilege, requiring holistic approaches to justice. Popularized by Kimberlé Crenshaw.

fields.name: Transgender Rights Movement
fields.description: A social and political movement focused on securing equality, healthcare access, and societal acceptance for transgender and gender-nonconforming individuals, often challenging binary gender norms.

fields.name: Social Justice Movement
fields.description: A broad ideology and movement advocating for equitable distribution of resources, opportunities, and rights, with a focus on dismantling systemic inequalities based on race, gender, class, or other markers.

fields.name: Antifa (Anti-Fascism)
fields.description: A decentralized political movement and ideology opposing fascism, racism, and authoritarianism through direct action, often including protest and confrontation. Rejects hierarchical organization.

fields.name: Critical Race Theory (CRT)
fields.description: An academic and ideological framework asserting that racism is embedded in legal, social, and economic systems, requiring structural change beyond individual prejudice. Originated in legal scholarship.

fields.name: Men’s Rights Movement
fields.description: A social and political movement advocating for the rights and interests of men, often focusing on issues like family law, gender roles, and perceived biases against men in modern society.

fields.name: Inclusivism
fields.description: An ideology promoting the inclusion of diverse identities and perspectives in social, political, and cultural spaces, often tied to policies like affirmative action or diversity quotas.
